sn16.8:4.1: Near Rājagaha, in the squirrels’ feeding ground.
sn16.8:4.2: Then Venerable Mahākassapa went up to the Buddha,
sn16.8:4.3: bowed, and sat down to one side.
sn16.8:4.7: Either you or I should advise the mendicants
sn16.8:4.8: and give them a Dhamma talk.”
sn16.8:5.1: “Sir, the mendicants these days are hard to correct, having qualities that make them hard to correct. They’re impatient, and don’t take instruction respectfully.”
sn16.8:5.2: “Kassapa, that’s because formerly the senior mendicants lived in the wilderness, ate only alms-food, wore rag robes, and owned just three robe; and they praised these things. They were of few wishes, content, secluded, aloof, and energetic; and they praised these things.
sn16.8:6.1: The senior mendicants invite such a mendicant to a seat, saying:
sn16.8:6.2: ‘Welcome, mendicant! What is this mendicant’s name? This mendicant is good-natured; he really wants to train.
sn16.8:7.2: ‘It seems that when a mendicant lives in the wilderness …
sn16.8:7.9: and is energetic, and praises these things, senior mendicants invite them to a seat …’
sn16.8:7.13: That is for their lasting welfare and happiness.
sn16.8:8.1: But these days, Kassapa, the senior mendicants don’t live in the wilderness … and aren’t energetic; and they don’t praise these things.
sn16.8:9.1: When a mendicant is well known and famous, a recipient of robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick, senior mendicants invite them to a seat:
sn16.8:9.2: ‘Welcome, mendicant! What is this mendicant’s name? This mendicant is good-natured; he really likes his fellow monks.
sn16.8:10.2: ‘It seems that when a mendicant is well known and famous, a recipient of robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick, senior mendicants invite them to a seat …’
sn16.8:10.6: That is for their lasting harm and suffering.
sn16.8:10.7: And if it could ever be rightly said that
sn16.8:10.8: spiritual practitioners are imperiled by the peril of a spiritual practitioner, and vanquished by the vanquishing of a spiritual practitioner, it is these days that this could be rightly said.”
